revision.text:
{{CIA}} [[Image:Ls-map.png|right|Map of the Principality of Liechtenstein]] [[Image:Lichtenstein NASA.png|thumb|Satellite image of Liechtenstein area, with the border shown in yellow]]
The principality of [[Liechtenstein]] encompasses most of the eastern half of the [[Rhine]] Valley, wedged between [[Austria]] and [[Switzerland]]. Majority of the country's population is found in the western half along the Rhine River. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ls.html|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}}</ref> Along with [[Uzbekistan]], Liechtenstein is one of only two [[landlocked country#Doubly landlocked_country|doubly landlocked countries]] in the world.
== Statistics == '''Geographic coordinates''': {{coord|47|10|N|9|32|E|region:LI_type:country|name=Liechtenstein}}
'''Area''': 160 km² (land, 0 km² water)
'''Land boundaries''' :''total:'' 76 km :''border countries:'' Austria 35 km, Switzerland 41 km
'''Lake''' :The only lake in Liechtenstein is the [[Gampriner Seele]].
'''Land use''' :''arable land:'' 21.88% :''permanent crops:'' 0% :''other:'' 78.12% (2011)
'''Terrain'''
:Mostly mountainous (Alps) with Rhine Valley in western third
'''Natural resources''': :[[Hydroelectricity|Hydroelectric]] potential, arable land
'''Extreme points:'''
* North - river [[Rhine]], [[Ruggell]] {{coord|47|16|15|N|9|31|51|E|type:landmark_region:LI|name=Rhine (North)}} * South - summit of [[Mazorakopf]]/Falknishorn (2,452 m), [[Triesen]] {{coord|47|2|55|N|9|33|26|E|type:mountain_region:LI|name=Mazerakopf (South)}} * East - border post 28, above [[Nenzinger Himmel]] * West - river Rhine, [[Balzers]] {{coord|47|3|46|N|9|28|18|E|region:LI_type:landmark|name=Rhine (West)}} * highest - [[Vorder Grauspitz]] (2,599 m), [[Triesen]] {{coord|47|3|10|N|9|34|54|E|region:LI_type:mountain|name=Vorder Grauspitz (highest)}} * lowest - [[Bangserfeld]] (429 m), [[Ruggell]] {{coord|47|15|57|N|9|32|14|E|region:LI_type:landmark|name=Bangserfeld (lowest)}}
== Climate == Continental; cold, cloudy winters with frequent snow or rain; cool to moderately warm, cloudy, humid summers, great variety of [[Microclimate|microclimates]] based on elevation
== Environment - international agreements: == ''Party to:''
[[Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution|Air Pollution]], Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, [[Nitrogen Oxide Protocol|Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides]], [[Sulphur Emissions Reduction Protocol (disambiguation)|Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Air Pollution-Sulphur 94]], [[Volatile Organic Compounds Protocol|Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds]], [[Convention on Biological Diversity|Biodiversity]], [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|Climate Change]], [[Kyoto Protocol|Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol]], [[United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification|Desertification]], [[Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora|Endangered Species]], [[Basel Convention|Hazardous Wastes]], [[Montreal Protocol on Substances That Deplete the Ozone Layer|Ozone Layer Protection]], [[Convention on Wetlands of International Importance Especially As Waterfowl Habitat|Wetlands]],
''Signed, but not ratified:''
[[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|Law of the Sea]]
== References == [[Category:Geography of Liechtenstein| ]] [[Category:Lists of coordinates]] [[Category:Liechtenstein-related lists|Extreme]] <references />{{CIA World Factbook}}{{Liechtenstein topics}} {{Geography of Europe}} {{Europe topic|Climate of}}
[[Category:Geography of Liechtenstein| ]] [[Category:Lists of coordinates]] [[Category:Liechtenstein-related lists|Extreme]]

page.title: Geology of the British Indian Ocean Territory

revision.comment: Alter: url, template type. Add: year, doi, pages, issue, volume, journal, author pars. 1-5. Removed accessdate with no specified URL. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
The '''geology of the [[British Indian Ocean Territory]]''' comprises the Chagos Archipelago—the above water portion of the [[Chagos Bank]]. Formed from hotspot volcanism, the Chagos Bank was separated from the [[Nazareth Bank]] 36 million years ago by activity on the Central Indian Ridge. Aside from plate boundaries, the region is one of the most seismically active and earthquakes have caused subsidence of some islands.
Described by Charles Darwin as "a ledge of brecciated coral rocks projecting seawards from the outer shore," the Chagos Archipelago has unusual [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] platforms. The islands lack [[Eemian]] age carbonates, which are present in the Seychelles for reasons that are not clear—hypothesized to include local storm erosion.<ref name="researchgate">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/230751432|date=2005-01-14|title= Reef and island formation and Late Holocene sea-level changes in the Chagos islands|author=A. Eisenhauer, G. A. Heiss, C. R. C. Sheppard, W.-C. Dullo|accessdate=2018-11-01}}</ref>
The offshore waters around the archipelago contain deep-sea ferromanganese nodules, with globular, dendritic and laminated microstructures formed from iron-manganese oxide.<ref name="sciencedirect">{{cite journal|title=Petrogenesis of ferromanganese nodules from east of the Chagos Archipelago, Central Indian Basin, Indian Ocean|journal=Marine Geology|volume=157|issue=3–4|pages=145–158|doi=10.1016/S0025-3227(98)00156-X|year=1999|last1=Banerjee|first1=Ranadip|last2=Roy|first2=Supriya|last3=Dasgupta|first3=Somnath|last4=Mukhopadhyay|first4=Subir|last5=Miura|first5=Hiroyuki}}</ref> Due to the US military presence on the island the US Geological Survey has conducted water resource analysis since 1984.
==References== {{reflist}} {{Asia topic|Geology of}}
[[Category:Geology of the British Indian Ocean Territory| ]] [[Category:Geology by country| British Indian Ocean Territory]]

revision.text:
{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:PS''' is the entry for the [[State of Palestine]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for the [[State of Palestine]], it claims the [[West Bank]] and the [[Gaza Strip]], but in fact controls only about 40% of the West Bank. ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[Governorates of the Palestinian National Authority|16 governorates]]. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|PS}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of the State of Palestine. The second part is three letters. ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). [[ISO 639-1]] codes are used to represent subdivision names in the following [[official language|administrative languages]]: * (ar): [[Arabic language|Arabic]] * (en): [[English language|English]] ===Governorates=== ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]]) ! Subdivision name ([[Arabic language|ar]]) |- | {{mono|PS-BTH}} | [[Bethlehem Governorate|Bethlehem]] | Bayt Laḩm |- | {{mono|PS-DEB}} | [[Deir al-Balah Governorate|Deir El Balah]] | Dayr al Balaḩ |- | {{mono|PS-GZA}} | [[Gaza Governorate|Gaza]] | Ghazzah |- | {{mono|PS-HBN}} | [[Hebron Governorate|Hebron]] | Al Khalīl |- | {{mono|PS-JEN}} | [[Jenin Governorate|Jenin]] | Janīn |- | {{mono|PS-JRH}} | [[Jericho Governorate|Jericho and Al Aghwar]] | Arīḩā wal Aghwār |- | {{mono|PS-JEM}} | [[Jerusalem Governorate|Jerusalem]] | Al Quds |- | {{mono|PS-KYS}} | [[Khan Yunis Governorate|Khan Yunis]] | Khān Yūnis |- | {{mono|PS-NBS}} | [[Nablus Governorate|Nablus]] | Nāblus |- | {{mono|PS-NGZ}} | [[North Gaza Governorate|North Gaza]] | Shamāl Ghazzah |- | {{mono|PS-QQA}} | [[Qalqilya Governorate|Qalqilya]] | Qalqīlyah |- | {{mono|PS-RFH}} | [[Rafah Governorate|Rafah]] | Rafaḩ |- | {{mono|PS-RBH}} | [[Ramallah and al-Bireh Governorate|Ramallah]] | Rām Allāh wal Bīrah |- | {{mono|PS-SLT}} | [[Salfit Governorate|Salfit]] | Salfīt |- | {{mono|PS-TBS}} | [[Tubas Governorate|Tubas]] | Ţūbās |- | {{mono|PS-TKM}} | [[Tulkarm Governorate|Tulkarm]] | Ţūlkarm |} ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced in newsletters by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter ! Code/Subdivision change |- | id="I-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_i-3_en.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-3}}] | {{nowrap|2002-08-20}} | Insertion of a new entry between PUERTO RICO and PORTUGAL; in accordance with [[ISO 3166-1#V-2|ISO 3166-1 Newsletter V-2]] | '''New entry''' (no codes) |- | id="II-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_ii-3_2011-12-13.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter II-3}}] | {{nowrap|2011-12-13}}
''(corrected
{{nowrap|2011-12-15}})'' | Administrative division taken into account. | style=white-space:nowrap | '''Subdivisions added:'''
16 governorates |} ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of the State of Palestine]] ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:PS ISO Online Browsing Platform: PS] {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:PS]] [[Category:Governorates of the Palestinian National Authority|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:State of Palestine-related lists]] [[Category:State of Palestine]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Inventing the Flat Earth''''' (1991; {{ISBN|978-0-275-95904-3}}) is a book by historian [[Jeffrey Burton Russell]] debunking the notion that medieval Christians believed the earth was flat.<ref>"... shows how nineteenth-century anti-Christians invented and spread the falsehood that educated people in the Middle Ages believed that the earth was flat" [http://www.asa3.org/ASA/topics/history/1997Russell.html Russell's summary of his book]</ref>
==See also== *[[Myth of the Flat Earth]]
==Notes== <references />
[[Category:1991 books]] [[Category:20th-century history books]] [[Category:History books about Christianity]] [[Category:History of geography]]
{{Europe-hist-book-stub}} {{christian-book-stub}}

revision.comment: The only part of Kazakhstan in Europe is the part west of the [[Ural River]]

{{Infobox protected area | name = Kirazlıbent Nature Park | alt_name = Kirazlıbent Tabiat Parkı | iucn_category = | photo = | photo_alt = | photo_caption = | photo_width = | map = Istanbul | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of the nature park in Istanbul, Turkey. | map_width = | relief = | label = Kirazlıbent NP | label_position = left | mark = | marker_size = | location = [[Kemerburgaz, Eyüp]], [[Istanbul Province]], Turkey | nearest_city = | coords = {{coord|41|10|13|N|28|57|46|E|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | area = {{convert|19.14|ha|acre|abbr=on}} | designation = | authorized = | created = | established = 2011 | designated = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = Directorate-General of Nature Protection and National Parks
[[Ministry of Environment and Forest (Turkey)|Ministry of Environment and Forest]] | administrator = | operator = | owner = | world_heritage_site = | website = | url = | child = | embedded = }} '''Kirazlıbent Nature Park''' ({{lang-tr|Kirazlıbent Tabiat Parkı}}) is a [[nature park]] located in [[Eyüp]] district of [[Istanbul Province]], Turkey. Kirazlıbent Nature Park is situated inside the [[Belgrad Forest]] in Eyüp. It is about {{convert|6|km|mi|abbr=on}} in distance west of [[Bahçeköy, Sarıyer|Bahçeköy]] and east of [[Kemerburgaz, Eyüp|Kemerburgaz]]. The area was declared a [[nature park]] by the [[Ministry of Environment and Forest (Turkey)|Ministry of Environment and Forest]] in 2011, and is one of the nine nature parks inside the Belgrad Forest. It covers an area of about {{convert|19.14|ha|abbr=on}}. The protected area is named after the dam Kirazlıbent, which was built by the [[Ottoman sultan]] [[Mahmud II]] (reigned 1808–1839) on Kirazlı Creek in 1818. The nature park offers outdoor recreation activities such as [[hiking]], cycling and [[picnic]]ing for visitors on daily basis.[2] There are playgrounds for children. Admission is charged for visitors and vehicles. ==Ecosystem== ; Flora The plants found in the forest area of the nature park are sessile oak (''[[Quercus petraea]]''), Kasnak oak (''[[Quercus vulcanica]]''), sweet chestnut (''[[Castanea sativa]]''), hornbeam (''[[Carpinus betulus]]''), black pine (''[[Pinus nigra]]''), oriental beech (''[[Fagus orientalis]]''), common ivy (''[[Hedera helix]]''), (''Smilax excelsa''), butcher's-broom (''[[Ruscus aculeatus]]'') and tree heath (''[[Erica arborea]]''). ;Fauna Animals observed in the nature park are the mammals [[red deer]], [[red fox]], [[wild boar]], [[golden jackal]], [[porcupine]], [[squirrel]], the reptile [[tortoise]] and the bird species [[European goldfinch|goldfinch]], [[passer]] and [[magpie]]. ==See also== * [[Ayvat Bendi Nature Park]] * [[Bentler Nature Park]] * [[Falih Rıfkı Atay Nature Park]] * [[Fatih Çeşmesi Nature Park]] * [[Irmak Nature Park]] * [[Kömürcübent Nature Park]] * [[Mehmet Akif Ersoy Nature Park]] * [[Neşet Suyu Nature Park]] ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.istanbultabiatparklari.gov.tr/tabiat-parklarimiz/tum-parklar/kirazlibent-tabiat-parki |publisher=İstanbul Tabiat Parkları |title=Kirazlıbant Tabiat Parkı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-05-05 }} {{cite web |url=http://istanbul.ormansu.gov.tr/istanbul/AnaSayfa/FotografGalerisi/kirazlibend.aspx?sflang=tr |publisher=Orman ve Su İşleri Bakanlığı-1. Bölge Müdürlüğü-İstanbul Şube Müdürlüğü |title=Tabiat Parkları - Kirazlıbend Tabiat Parkı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2017-05-05 }} }} {{Nature parks of Turkey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kirazlibent Nature Park}} [[Category:Nature parks in Turkey]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2011]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Turkey]] [[Category:Parks in Istanbul]] [[Category:Eyüp]] [[Category:Belgrad Forest]] {{Istanbul-geo-stub}} {{protected-area-stub}}

page.title: List of World Heritage sites in China

revision.comment: ce case
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} [[File:Flag of the People's Republic of China.svg|thumb|200px| <center>[[File:Welterbe.svg|55px]] [[File:UNESCO logo.svg|70px]]</center> ]] This is a list of [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage site]]s in [[China]]. China has 53, ranking [[Table of World Heritage sites by country|second in the world]]. China ratified The Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage on 12 December 1985. These sites comprise some of the most essential part of China's valuable and rich [[Tourism in China|tourism]] resources.
==Overview== Since joining the International Convention Concerning the Protection of World Cultural and Natural Heritage in 1985, China has 53 world heritage sites to date; of these 36 are cultural heritage sites, 13 are natural heritage sites, and 4 are cultural and natural (mixed) sites, ranking second in the world.
In addition, there are also several Chinese documents inscribed in UNESCO's list [[Memory of the World Programme|Memory of the World]], which registers the world's documentary heritage. Furthermore, China has a rich non-material cultural heritage, with several of them inscribed on UNESCO's list of [[Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity]].
==Map== Following is a map of the World Heritage sites in China.
Numbered sites around Beijing: 1. [[Great Wall of China|Great Wall]]; 2. [[Forbidden City]]; 3. [[Zhoukoudian]]; 4. [[Summer Palace]]; 5. [[Temple of Heaven]]; 6. [[Ming Dynasty Tombs]]; 7. [[Eastern Qing Tombs]]; 8. [[Western Qing Tombs]]

== Tentative list == There are the sites China has submitted to the UNESCO World Heritage tentative list.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/state=cn|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – Tentative Lists|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> * [[Dongzhai Port Nature Reserve]] (1996) * The [[Chinese alligator|Alligator Sinensis]] Nature Reserve (1996) * [[Poyang Lake|Poyang]] Nature Reserve (1996) * The [[Li River|Lijiang River]] Scenic Zone at Guilin (1996) * Yalong, Tibet (2001) * [[Three Gorges|Yangtze Gorges]] Scenic Spot (2001) * [[Mount Jinfo|Jinfushan]] Scenic Spot (2001) * [[Xiaozhai Tiankeng|Heaven Pit]] and Ground Seam Scenic Spot (2001) * [[Hua Shan]] Scenic Area (2001) * [[Yandang Mountain]] (2001) * [[Nanxi River (Zhejiang)|Nanxi River]] (2001) * [[Maijishan Grottoes|Maijishan]] Scenic Spots (2001) * [[Wudalianchi]] Scenic Spots (2001) * [[Pingtan Island|Haitan]] Scenic Spots (2001) * [[Cang Mountain|Dali Cangshan Mountain]] and [[Erhai Lake]] Scenic Spot (2001) * Sites for [[Chinese Liquor Making Sites|Liquor Making in China]] (2008) * Ancient Residences in [[Shanxi]] and [[Shaanxi]] Provinces (2008) * [[City Walls of the Ming and Qing Dynasties]] (2008) * [[Slender West Lake]] and Historic Urban Area in [[Yangzhou]] (2008) * Ancient Water Towns South of the [[Yangtze]] River ([[Zhouzhuang]], [[Luzhi]], [[Wuzhen]], and [[Xitang]]) (2008) * [[Fenghuang County|Fenghuang Ancient City]] (2008) * Sites of the [[Nanyue|Southern Yue]] State (2008) * [[Baiheliang]] Ancient Hydrological Inscription (2008) * [[Miao people|Miao]] Nationality Villages in Southeast [[Guizhou|Guizhou Province]]: The villages of Miao Nationality at the Foot of Leigong Mountain in Miao Ling Mountains (2008) * [[Karez well system|Karez Wells]] (2008) * Expansion Project of Imperial Tombs of the Ming and Qing Dynasties: King Lujian’s Tombs (2008) * The [[Sacred Mountains of China|Four Sacred Mountains]] as an extension of [[Mount Tai|Mt. Taishan]] (2008) * [[Taklimakan Desert]]–[[Populus euphratica]] Forests (2010) * China [[Altai Mountains|Altay]] (2010) * [[Karakorum]]–[[Pamir Mountains|Pamir]] (2010) * The Central Axis of [[Beijing]] (including Beihai) (2013) * Wooden Structures of [[Liao dynasty|Liao Dynasty]] – [[Pagoda of Fogong Temple|Wooden Pagoda of Yingxian County]], Main Hall of [[Fengguo Temple|Fengguo Monastery]] of Yixian County (2013) * Sites of the [[Hongshan Culture]]: [[Niuheliang]], [[Hongshanhou]], and Weijiawopu (2013) * [[Liangzhu culture|Liangzhu]] Archaeological Site (2013) * Ancient Porcelain Kiln Site in China (2013) * [[Sanfang Qixiang]] (2013) * Ancient Tea Plantations of Jingmai Mountain in [[Pu'er City|Pu'er]] (2013) * [[Western Xia mausoleums|Western Xia Imperial Tombs]] (2013) * [[Dong people|Dong]] Villages (2013) * [[Lingqu|Lingqu Canal]] (2013) * Diaolou Buildings and Villages for [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]] and [[Qiang people|Qiang]] Ethnic Groups (2013) * Archaeological Sites of the Ancient [[Shu (state)|Shu State]]: [[Jinsha site]] and Joint Tombs of Boat-shaped Coffins in [[Chengdu]], Sichuan; [[Sanxingdui]] site in [[Guanghan]], 29th – 5th century BC (2013) * [[Xinjiang]] [[Yardang]] (2015) * [[Dunhuang]] Yardangs (2015) * [[Mount Tianzhu|Tianzhushan]] (2015) * [[Jinggang Mountains|Jinggangshan]]–North [[Wuyi Mountains|Wuyishan]] (extension of Mount Wuyi) (2015) * [[Shudao]] (2015) * Tulin–[[Guge]] Scenic and Historic Interest Areas (2015) * Historic Monuments and Sites of Ancient [[Quanzhou]] (Zayton) (2016) * The Chinese Section of the [[Silk Road]]s (2016) * Guancen Mountain – Luya Mountain (2017) * [[Hulunbuir|Hulun Buir]] Landscape & Birthplace of Ancient Minority (2017) * [[Qinghai Lake]] (2017) * Scenic and historic area of Sacred Mountains and Lakes ([[Mount Kailash|Gang Rinpoche]], [[Gurla Mandhata|Naimona'nyi]], [[Lake Manasarovar]] and [[Lhanag-tso]]) (2017) * [[Taihang Mountains|Taihang]] Mountain (2017) * The Coast of the [[Bohai Sea|Bohai Gulf]] and the Yellow Sea of China (2017) * Vertical Vegetation Landscape and Volcanic Landscape in [[Changbai Mountains|Changbai Mountain]] (2017)
==Performance of China in UNESCO== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !UNESCO List !! Exclusive Entries of China, People's Republic !! Shared/Multinational Entries Involving China, People's Republic |- |[[World Network of Biosphere Reserves|UNESCO World Network of Biosphere Reserves]] || 33 || {{sort|0|—}} |- |[[World Heritage List|UNESCO World Heritage List]] || 53 || 1 |- |[[Memory of the World Register|UNESCO Memory of the World Register]] || 13 || {{sort|0|—}} |- |[[Global Geoparks Network|UNESCO Global Geoparks Network]] || 37 || {{sort|0|—}} |- |[[Creative Cities Network|UNESCO Creative Cities Network]] || 12 || {{sort|0|—}} |- |[[UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists]] || 39 || 1 |}

page.title: List of countries and dependencies and their capitals in native languages

revision.comment: /* E */ Looks like we're going with Eswatini as the common English name, per the page title move discussion.
revision.text:
The following chart lists [[List of sovereign states|countries]] and [[Dependent territory|dependencies]] along with their [[Capital (political)|capital]] cities, in English as well as any additional [[official language]](s). * In '''bold''': [[List of sovereign states|Internationally recognized sovereign states]] ** The 193 [[List of United Nations member states|member states]] of the [[United Nations]] (UN) ** [[Vatican City]] (administered by the [[Holy See]], a [[United Nations General Assembly observers#Non-member states|UN observer state]]), which is generally recognized as a sovereign state * In '''''bold italics''''': [[List of states with limited recognition|States with limited recognition]] and [[associated state]]s not members of the United Nations ** ''De facto'' sovereign states with partial international recognition, such as the [[State of Palestine]], the [[Republic of Kosovo]] and [[Taiwan]] ** ''De facto'' sovereign states lacking general international recognition ** [[Cook Islands]] and [[Niue]], two [[Realm of New Zealand|associated states of New Zealand]] without UN membership * In ''italics'': Non-sovereign territories that are recognized by the UN as part of some member state ** [[List of dependent territories|Dependent territories]] ** Special territories recognized by international treaty (such as the [[Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China|special administrative regions of China]]) ** Other territories often regarded as separate geographical territories even though they are integral parts of their mother countries (such as the [[Overseas departments and territories of France|overseas departments of France]]) {{Compact ToC |center = yes |sep = middot; |nobreak = yes |seealso = yes |custom1 = Notes }} ==A== {| style="text-align:center;" class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" ! ([[Arabic script]]) |} ==Z== {| style="text-align:center;" class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" ! style="width:175px;"|Country ([[exonym]]) ! style="width:175px;"|Capital ([[exonym]]) ! style="width:175px;"|Country ([[endonym]]) ! style="width:175px;"|Capital ([[endonym]]) ! style="width:175px;"|Official or native language(s) (alphabet/script) |- |{{flagicon|Zambia}} '''[[Zambia]]''' || [[Lusaka]] || '''Zambia''' || '''Lusaka''' || [[English language|English]], [[Bemba language|Bemba]], [[Chewa language|Chewa]] |- |{{flagicon|Zimbabwe}} '''[[Zimbabwe]]''' || [[Harare]] || '''Zimbabwe''' || '''Harare''' || [[English language|English]], [[Shona language|Shona]] |} ==Notes== {{notelist | refs =30em {{efn | name = a | [[Jerusalem Law]] states that "Jerusalem, complete and united, is the capital of Israel", and the city serves as the seat of the government, home to the president's residence, government offices, supreme court, and parliament. [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 478]] declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem. The United Nations and nearly all of its member states maintain their embassies in other cities such as [[Tel Aviv]], [[Ramat Gan]], and [[Herzliya]], and do not recognise Jerusalem as the capital;See the [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/is.html CIA Factbook] and [https://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/israel.pdf Map of Israel] however, in May 2018, the [[United States]] and [[Guatemala]] moved their official embassies to Jerusalem, and several other UN member states indicated that they were considering doing the same.[https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/17/after-us-embassy-move-to-jerusalem-more-countries-follow-its-lead.html See] Many countries officially adhere to the proposal that Jerusalem have international status, as called for in the [[United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine|Partition Plan]] of 1947. The [[Palestinian National Authority]] claims East Jerusalem as the capital of a future Palestinian state.{{cite book |last=Sharkansky |first=Ira |authorlink=Ira Sharkansky |title=Governing Jerusalem: Again on the world's agenda |page=23 |publisher=Wayne State University Press |year=1996 |isbn=0-8143-2592-0}} See [[Positions on Jerusalem]]. }} {{efn | name = b |The State of Palestine claims the territories occupied by Israel since the [[Six-Day War]] in 1967, with [[East Jerusalem]] as its capital. The proclaimed state is currently occupied by Israel and has no effective control over the territories it claims. Administration is based in [[Ramallah]] and [[Gaza City|Gaza]], rather than Jerusalem. Most members of the United Nations regard East Jerusalem as occupied territory, and the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]], the [[Arab League]] and the [[Non-Aligned Movement]] recognise it as the capital of a future Palestinian state. See the following: *{{Cite web|author=Organisation of the Islamic Conference|title=Resolutions on Political, Legal and Information Affairs|work=The Eighteenth Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers (Session of Islamic Fraternity and Solidarity)|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/english/conf/fm/18/18%20icfm-political-en.htm|date=13–16 March 1989|accessdate=2011-10-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924055432/http://www.oic-oci.org/english/conf/fm/18/18%20icfm-political-en.htm|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}} *{{Cite news|author=Agence France-Presse|title=Non-Aligned movement confirms support for Palestinian statehood bid|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/09/06/165700.html|newspaper=Al Arabiya|date=6 September 2011|accessdate=2011-10-18}} *{{Cite web|author=Council of the European Union, 17218/09 (Presse 371)|title=Press release, 2985th Council meeting on Foreign Affairs|url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cms_data/docs/pressdata/EN/foraff/111833.pdf|archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091222225739/http://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cms_data/docs/pressdata/EN/foraff/111833.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-12-22|publisher=Press Office|accessdate=2011-08-02}} See [[Positions on Jerusalem]].}} }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Countries and languages lists}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Countries And Capitals In Native Languages, List Of}} [[Category:Lists of country names|Native]] [[Category:Exonyms]]

revision.text:
{{expand list|date=June 2012}} There are many examples of [[spit (landform)|spits]] around the world. Some of which include:
== By sea ==
===Azov Sea=== {{main|Spits of Azov Sea}} ;[[Russia]] * [[Achuevsk Spit]] * [[Beglitsk Spit]] * [[Chushka Spit]] * [[Dolgaya Spit]] * [[Glafirovsk Spit]] * [[Kamyshevatsk Spit]] * [[Gully of Petrushino|Petrushin Spit]] * [[Sazalniksk Spit]] * [[Yasensk Spit]] * [[Yeysk|Yeysk Spit]] ;[[Ukraine]] * [[Belosaraysk Spit]] * [[Berdyansk Spit]] * [[Fedotova Spit]] * [[Krivaya Spit]] * [[Obytichna Spit]] ; [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Disputed between Russia and Ukraine]] * [[Arabat Spit]] * [[Tuzla Spit]]
===Baltic Sea=== * [[Curonian Spit]], [[Russia]]/[[Lithuania]] * [[Grenen]], [[Denmark]] * [[Hel peninsula|Hel Spit]], [[Poland]] * [[Priwall Peninsula|Priwall]], [[Germany]] * [[Vistula Spit]], [[Poland]]/[[Russia]]
== By country ==
===Australia=== *[[Lefevre Peninsula]], [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] *[[Letitia Spit]], [[Fingal Head]], [[New South Wales]] *[[Tobias Spit]], 1 km northeast of High Island, [[Frankland Islands]], [[Queensland]]
===Canada=== *[[Toronto Islands]] (former spit, now detached), [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]] *[[Leslie Street Spit]], man-made spit created as part of new harbour project *[[Long Point, Ontario|Long Point]], [[Ontario]] *[[Point Pelee National Park|Point Pelee, Ontario]] on [[Lake Erie]] *[[Rondeau Provincial Park]] - a crescentric sand spit on [[Lake Erie]] *Blackie Spit (east section of the [[Crescent Beach (Surrey)|Crescent Beach]]), [[South Surrey]], [[British Columbia]] [http://www.surrey.ca/Living+in+Surrey/Parks+and+Recreation/Parks+and+Environment/Park+Locations+and+Amenities/Parks+by+Community+Area/South+Surrey/Blackie+Spit+Park.htm] * [[Sidney Spit]], [[Sidney Island]], [[British Columbia]] * La Dune de Bouctouche, [[Bouctouche]], [[New Brunswick]][https://web.archive.org/web/19981212030031/http://www.irvingecocenter.com/] * [[Whiffen Spit]], [[Sooke]], [[British Columbia]] *West Pen Island, [[Nunavut]]
===Croatia=== [[File:Bol na Bracu - Zlatni rat.jpg|thumb|180px|Zlatni Rat, Croatia]] *[[Zlatni Rat]], on island [[Brač]]
=== Denmark === [[File:Skagen aka the skaw northmost point of denmark 6th may 2006.jpg|thumb|180px|Grenen, Denmark]] *[[Grenen]], the tip of the [[Jutland]] peninsula
===Hong Kong=== *[[Pui O]], [[Lantau]] *[[Tsim Sha Tsui]] before infilling *Stanley *Discovery bay *Central ferry pier
===Republic of Ireland=== *[[Inch Strand]], [[Dingle Peninsula]], [[County Kerry]]. *[[Donabate Beach]], [[Donabate]], [[County Dublin]]. *[[Portrane Beach]], [[Portrane]], [[County Dublin]].
===Jamaica=== *[[Palisadoes]], [[Kingston, Jamaica]]
===New Zealand=== *[[Aramoana]], [[Otago]] *[[Farewell Spit]], [[South Island]]
===Pakistan=== *[[Sandspit Beach|Sandspit]], [[Karachi]] <ref>[http://wikimapia.org/#lat=24.8247554&lon=66.9343758&z=13&l=0&m=a&v=2 Sandspit, Karachi, Satellite View]</ref>
=== Russia === * [[Russkaya Koshka]], [[Chukotka Autonomous Okrug|Chukotka]]
===Singapore=== *[[Changi Beach]]
=== Spain === * [[Cadiz]], [[Andalusia]] * [[La Manga]], [[Mar Menor]], [[Region of Murcia]]
===United Kingdom=== *[[Blakeney Point]], [[Norfolk]] *[[Calshot Spit]], [[Hampshire]] *[[Chesil Beach]], [[Dorset]] *[[Conwy Morfa]], [[Conwy County Borough|Conwy]] *[[Dawlish Warren]], [[Devon]] *[[East Head Spit]], Hampshire *[[Fairbourne Spit]], [[Fairbourne]], [[Gwynedd]] *[[Hengistbury Head]], Dorset *[[Hurst Spit]], Hampshire *[[Mudeford Spit]], Dorset *[[Orford Ness]], [[Suffolk]] *[[Spurn|Spurn Head]], [[Yorkshire]]
===United States=== *[[Bodie Island]] and the [[Currituck Banks]], on both sides of the border between [[Virginia]] and [[North Carolina]], the northernmost of the [[Outer Banks]] *[[Clatsop Spit]], [[Oregon]] *[[Deveaux Bank]], [[South Carolina]] *[[Dungeness Spit]], [[Sequim, Washington]], the longest natural sand spit in the United States. *[[Ediz Hook]], [[Port Angeles, Washington]] *[[Fenwick Island (Delaware–Maryland)|Fenwick Island]], on both sides of the border of [[Delaware]] and [[Maryland]] *[[Homer Spit]], [[Homer, Alaska]] *[[Kotzebue, Alaska]] *[[Long Point (Cape Cod)|Long Point]], [[Provincetown, Massachusetts#Geography|Provincetown, Massachusetts]], at the tip of [[Cape Cod]] *[[Minnesota Point]], [[Duluth, Minnesota]] Also referred to by locals as "Park Point", it's also said to be the world's largest freshwater natural spit. *[[Presque Isle State Park|Presque Isle]], [[Erie, Pennsylvania]] *[[Provincetown Spit]], [[Massachusetts]] *[[Sandy Hook (New Jersey)|Sandy Hook]], [[New Jersey]] *[[The Spit, Massachusetts|The Spit]], [[Scituate, Massachusetts]] *[[Willoughby Spit]], [[Norfolk, Virginia]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Earth's landforms}}
[[Category:Geography-related lists|Spits]] [[Category:Spits (landform)|*]]

page.title: List of tourist attractions in Sheffield

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in the United Kingdom]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
As a large city, [[Sheffield]], [[South Yorkshire]], England, has many tourist attractions from performing arts centres to museums, shopping centres and public parks. Below is a list of some of the more famous and visited:
{{EngPlacesKey}}
*[[Abbeydale Industrial Hamlet]] [[Image:Museum icon (red).png]] *[[Arts Tower]] *[[Beauchief Abbey]] [[Image: AP Icon.svg]] *[[Birley Spa]] *[[Bishops' House]] [[Image:HH icon.png]] *[[Crucible Theatre]] *[[Cutlers' Hall]] *[[Devonshire Quarter|Devonshire Green]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Don Valley Stadium]] *[[Dore|The Dore Stone]] *[[Endcliffe Park]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Graves Art Gallery]] *[[Graves Park]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[IceSheffield]] *[[Kelham Island Museum]] [[Image:Museum icon (red).png]] *[[Lyceum Theatre (Sheffield)|Lyceum Theatre]] *[[Magna Science Adventure Centre]] *[[Meadowhall Shopping Centre]] *[[Millennium Galleries]] *[[Millhouses Park]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Old Queen's Head, Sheffield|Old Queen's Head]] *[[Peace Gardens]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Ponds Forge]] *[[Rivelin Valley]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Rother Valley Country Park]] [[Image:CP icon.png]] *[[Sheaf Square]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Sheffield Arena]] *[[Sheffield Botanical Gardens]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Sheffield Cathedral]] [[Image: AP Icon.svg]] *[[Sheffield City Hall]] *[[Sheffield Fire and Police Museum]] [[Image:Museum icon (red).png]] *[[Sheffield Manor]] *[[Sheffield Town Hall]] *[[Sheffield Walk of Fame]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Sheffield Winter Gardens]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Shepherd Wheel]] *[[Showroom Cinema]] *[[Site Gallery]] *[[Valley Centertainment]] *[[Victoria Quays]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Weston Park Museum]] [[Image:Museum icon.png]] *[[Wheel of Sheffield]] *[[Wincobank (hill fort)]] [[Image:UKAL icon.png]] *[[Yorkshire ArtSpace]] [[Category:Sheffield-related lists|Tourist]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Sheffield| ]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions by city|Sheffield]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Manouchehr Sotodeh
{{lang|fa|منوچهر ستوده}} | image = Manochehr Sotoudeh.jpg | image_size = | caption = Manouchehr Sotodeh | birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|07|19|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]], Iran | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|04|8|1913|07|19|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Chalus, Iran|Chalus]], Iran | death_cause = | occupation = {{hlist|Geographer|scholar}} | nationality = Iranian | website = [http://drsotoudeh.ir/ Official website] }} '''Manouchehr Sotodeh''' ({{lang-fa|منوچهر ستوده}}, 19 July 1913 – 8 April 2016) was an Iranian [[geography|geographer]] and scholar of [[Persian literature]]. He wrote 60 books and nearly 300 articles. He is the first Iranian who published the first dialectal dictionary. He was also a professor of [[University of Tehran]].[https://www.mazandnume.com/fullcontent/15741/دیگه-هیچ-آرزویی-ندارم! !دیگه هیچ آرزویی ندارم] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419080937/http://www.mazandnume.com/fullcontent/15741/%D8%AF%DB%8C%DA%AF%D9%87-%D9%87%DB%8C%DA%86-%D8%A2%D8%B1%D8%B2%D9%88%DB%8C%DB%8C-%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%85%21/ |date=2016-04-19 }} == Notes == {{Reflist}} == See also == * [[Persian literature]] * [[Badiozzaman Forouzanfar]] * [[Five-Masters]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sotodeh, Manouchehr}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Iranian writers]] [[Category:Iranian literary scholars]] [[Category:Iranian academics]] [[Category:Iranian geographers]] [[Category:Iranian centenarians]] [[Category:Iranian lexicographers]] [[Category:University of Tehran faculty]] [[Category:People from Mazandaran Province]] [[Category:Members of the Academy of Persian Language and Literature]] {{Iran-linguist-stub}} [[Category:People from Nur]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ remove link to website of no encyclopedic value
revision.text:
[[File:Jordan nature reserves location map.svg|thumb|upright|Approximate locations of the first six reserves]] There are at least seven '''[[nature reserves]] in [[Jordan]]'''. In 1966, the organization that would later start Jordan's nature reserves, the [[Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature]], was founded. RSCN's first efforts involved bringing back severely endangered species. In 1973, RSCN, was given the right to issue [[hunting license]]s, giving RSCN an upper hand in preventing extinction. The first step was the founding of Jordan's first nature reserve, [[Shaumari Wildlife Reserve]], in 1975. The primary purpose was to create means to breed endangered species, specifically: the [[Arabian oryx]], [[gazelles]], [[ostriches]] and [[Persian onager]]s in their natural environment.
In 1994, shortly after [[Dana Biosphere Reserve]] was established, RSCN began its Research and Survey section, made up of experienced researchers with the primary goal of collecting information at the reserves needed to create a sustainable living environment for wild animals through scientific research. Shortly thereafter, Wild Jordan was created as a business branch of RSCN dealing with socio-economic projects. In 1999, RSCN started a training program to build local and regional skill in conserving nature. RSCN raised more awareness in 2005 with a "Save Jordan's Trees" campaign. Jordan's sixth and latest nature reserve, [[Dibeen Forest Reserve]], was created in 2004, cementing {{convert|1200|km2|sqmi|0|}} of protected natural landscape throughout Jordan.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Full Story|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/AboutRSCN/History/TheFullStory/tabid/128/Default.aspx|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature|accessdate=2009-06-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608134010/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/AboutRSCN/History/TheFullStory/tabid/128/Default.aspx|archivedate=2010-06-08|df=}}</ref>
In addition, there are eight proposed nature reserves in Jordan, and two more sites that are possible candidates for preservation.<ref name="prop">{{cite web|title=Proposed Protected Areas|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/ProposedProtectedAreas/tabid/100/Default.aspx|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation for Nature|accessdate=2009-06-16|year=2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503071900/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/ProposedProtectedAreas/tabid/100/Default.aspx|archivedate=2009-05-03|df=}}</ref><ref name="prot">{{cite web|title=Protected Areas|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/tabid/91/Default.aspx|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation for Nature|accessdate=2009-06-16|year=2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150420011813/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/tabid/91/Default.aspx|archivedate=2015-04-20|df=}}</ref>
==Reserves== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Reserve ! Location ! Size ! Date established ! Notes |- | [[Dana Biosphere Reserve]] | South-central | {{convert|320|km2|0}} | 1993 | Largest nature reserve in Jordan<ref name="dana">{{cite web|url=http://www.jordanjubilee.com/outdoors/dana.htm|title=Nature Reserve of Dana|publisher=Jordan Jubilee|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref> |- | [[Wadi Mujib|Mujib Nature Reserve]] | Eastern shore of the [[Dead Sea]] | {{convert|220|km2|0}} | 1987 | Lowest nature reserve in the world<ref name="mujib">{{cite web|url=http://www.jordanjubilee.com/outdoors/wadimujib.htm|title=Wadi Mujib|accessdate=2009-04-04|publisher=Jordan Jubilee|year=2000}}</ref> |- | [[Ajloun Forest Reserve]] | Northwest | {{convert|13|km2|0}} | 1988<ref name="ajloun">{{cite web|url=http://www.jordanjubilee.com/outdoors/ajloun.htm|title=Nature Reserve of Ajloun|publisher=Jordan Jubilee|accessdate=2009-04-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303194435/http://www.jordanjubilee.com/outdoors/ajloun.htm|archivedate=2009-03-03|df=}}</ref> | |- | [[Dibeen Forest Reserve]] | Northwest | {{convert|8.5|km2|0}} | 2004 | Smallest reserve in Jordan<ref name="dibeen">{{cite web|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/DibeenForestReserve/tabid/97/Default.aspx|title=Dibeen Forest Reserve|publisher=Jordan Society for the Conservation of Nature|accessdate=2008-06-25|year=2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624104101/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/DibeenForestReserve/tabid/97/Default.aspx|archivedate=2008-06-24|df=}}</ref> |- | [[Azraq Wetland Reserve]] | Northeast | {{convert|12|km2|0}} | 1978 | Only wetland reserve in Jordan<ref name="azraq">{{cite web|url=http://www.jordanjubilee.com/outdoors/azraq.htm|title=Reserves of Azraq and Shaumari|publisher=Jordan Jubilee|accessdate=2009-04-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503213845/http://www.jordanjubilee.com/outdoors/azraq.htm|archivedate=2009-05-03|df=}}</ref> |- | [[Shaumari Wildlife Reserve]] | Northeast | {{convert|22|km2|0}} | 1975<ref name="azraq"/> | |- | [[Fifa Nature Reserve]] | Southwest | {{convert|23.2|km2|0}} | 2011<ref name="Fifa"/> | |- |}
===Dana Biosphere Reserve=== [[File:Danagorge.jpg|thumb|left|Dana Gorge]] Dana Biosphere Reserve, often simply called Dana Nature Reserve, is Jordan's largest reserve, located in and around the town of [[Dana, Jordan|Dana]] in the mountains east of [[Wadi Araba]]. The geography of the reserve is characterized by steep cliffs in rocky wadis covered by small trees and shrubs. The varied geology switches from [[limestone]] to [[sandstone]] to [[granite]]. Some illegal activities such as grazing and woodcutting continue. Illegal hunting threatens [[ibex]] and [[chukar partridge|chukar]] populations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dana Biosphere Reserve|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/DanaBiosphereReserve/tabid/93/Default.aspx|accessdate=2009-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516082613/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/DanaBiosphereReserve/tabid/93/Default.aspx|archivedate=2011-05-16|df=}}</ref>
===Wadi Mujib=== [[File:Wadi Mujib4.jpeg|thumb|right|Wadi Mujib]] Mujib Nature Reserve, commonly known as Wadi Mujib, is a long canyon feeding the [[Dead Sea]] running through the ancient region of [[Moab]] and the lowest nature reserve in the world. Directly east of the Dead Sea, Wadi Mujib is made up by a network of freshwater streams, making an otherwise arid area more fertile. The lush riverbeds provide support for aquatic plants. As well as containing 300 species of plants, Wadi Mujib contains at least 10 species of carnivores and other animals, including the hyrax, badger, and the Nubian ibex which was reintroduced into the wild by RSCN. Illegal hunting continues to impede efforts to reach a sustainable number of wild ibexes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mujib Nature Reserve|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/MujibNatureReserve/tabid/94/Default.aspx|accessdate=2009-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624104739/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/MujibNatureReserve/tabid/94/Default.aspx|archivedate=2008-06-24|df=}}</ref>
===Ajloun Reserve=== [[File:Ajlun Green.jpg|thumb|left|Ajloun forest]] Ajloun Forest Reserve is in north Jordan, near [[Jerash]] and [[Ajloun]], and close to the [[Ajloun Castle]]. The reserve consists of rolling hills in a Mediterranean-like environment, covered in [[oak|evergreen oaks]], as well as strawberry and pistachio trees, among others. [[Stone marten]]s, [[jackals]], [[red foxes]], [[striped hyena]]s, [[Persian squirrel]]s, [[porcupines]], and [[wolves]] inhabit this area. Privately owned lands surrounding the reserve pose threats, including illegitimate access to the reserve, resulting in illegal hunting, woodcutting, and grazing. Cooperation with local inhabitants has resulted in increased awareness in the community regarding the preservation of the forest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ajloun Forest Reserve|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/AjlounForestReserve/tabid/96/Default.aspx|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature|accessdate=2009-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712041505/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/AjlounForestReserve/tabid/96/Default.aspx|archivedate=2012-07-12|df=}}</ref>
===Dibeen Forest Reserve=== [[File:Dibeen Trees.jpg|thumb|right|Vista in Dibeen]] Dibeen Forest, close to the ancient Roman city of [[Jerash]], is the newest reserve in Jordan, established in 2004. The forest is a pine-oak habitat, housing the [[Aleppo pine]] and marking the geographical limit of this type of forest. Animal inhabitants such as the [[Persian squirrel]] were main reasons for the establishment of the reserve and were considered top priority. Strawberry, pistachio, and wild olive trees also grow in the reserve. Trash, notably [[plastic]], presents a major problem in the reserve, often the result of careless visitors.<ref name="dibeen"/>
===Azraq Wetland Reserve=== [[File:Azraq view.jpg|thumb|left|Azraq wetland]] The Azraq Wetlands, located in Jordan's eastern desert near the town of [[Azraq, Jordan|Azraq]], is RSCN's only wetlands reserve. The reserve, once a popular stopover for millions of migratory birds going from [[Africa]] to [[Eurasia]], is now severely depleted due to over-pumping to support Jordan's growing population. In 1978, the reserve was established as an effort to conserve the oasis. Between 1981 and 1993, water levels decreased sharply, concluding with the drying up of the springs in 1992. Azraq today only makes up 0.04% of its former size. Water levels are maintained by RSCN in order to save indigenous fish species such as the Azraq Killfish and to keep the site a tourist destination. Efforts have been partially successful; some birds have returned and killfish have increased in numbers, but attempts to increase the water mass by 10% of the original size have been unsuccessful. Water pumping and lack of manpower and wetland experience keep water levels at a low.<ref>{{cite web|title=Azraq Wetlands Reserve|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/AzraqWetlandReserve/tabid/98/Default.aspx|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature|accessdate=2009-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624104203/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/AzraqWetlandReserve/tabid/98/Default.aspx|archivedate=2008-06-24|df=}}</ref>
===Shaumari Reserve=== [[File:Shaumarinaturereserve.jpg|thumb|right|Reeds in Shaumari]] Shaumari Wildlife Reserve is located in the eastern Jordanian desert, close to [[Azraq Wetland Reserve]]. The geology comprises desert wadis making up 65% of the area and Hammada areas covered in black flint forming 35% of the reserve. Founded in 1975, Shaumari was founded for the wildlife in the desert area. One of the main goals of the reserve has been to bring back locally extinct species, notably the [[Arabian oryx]], into the wild. In 1978, 4 Arabian oryxs were brought to the reserve for a breeding program. Starting in 1983, 31 oryxs were released into the wild, successfully returning the oryx into its native environment. Other species, such as [[Somali ostrich]]es, [[Persian onager]]s and [[gazelle]]s reside in the reserve. Before the establishment of the reserve, hunting nearly annihilated local animal populations, a problem which RSCN has been successful in dealing with.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shaumari Wildlife Reserve|publisher=Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature|url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/ShaumariWildlifeReserve/tabid/95/Default.aspx|accessdate=2009-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430193138/http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/ShaumariWildlifeReserve/tabid/95/Default.aspx|archivedate=2009-04-30|df=}}</ref>
===Fifa Nature Reserve=== On July 13, 2011, the Fifa Nature Reserve was officially declared. It is located in the south-western part of Jordan. The reserve has an area of 23.2 km<sup>2</sup>. In part lying well below sea level, the reserve contains the salt plant pattern and the tropical plant pattern.<ref name="Fifa">{{cite web |url=http://www.rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/FifaNatureReserve/tabid/338/Default.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141224195725/http://rscn.org.jo/orgsite/RSCN/HelpingNature/ProtectedAreas/FifaNatureReserve/tabid/338/Default.aspx |archivedate=2014-12-24 |df= }}, accessed 2014-11-02</ref>
==Future== {{Expand section|date=May 2009}} The Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature has expressed interest in creating up to nine new nature reserves in Jordan.<ref name="rw">{{cite journal |last=Taylor |first=Eddie|date=March–April 2009 |title=Protect & Serve |journal=Royal Wings |volume= |issue= |pages=35–37 }}</ref> One of these, Fifa, was established in 2011. There were also two other sites mentioned in two reports issued in 1979 and 1998 on the feasibility of new reserve sites around the country.<ref name="prot"/> The nine that RSCN have expressed interest in include:<ref name="prop"/> *'''Burqu’''' *'''Yarmouk River''' *'''Qatar''' *'''Jabal Mas’uda''' *'''Aqaba Mountains''' *'''Rajel''' *'''Abu Rukbeh''' *'''Bayer'''
The two additional sites are:<ref name="prot"/> *'''Jarba''' *'''Jordan River'''
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.rscn.org.jo/ Royal Society for the Conservation of Nature website]
{{Nature reserves in Jordan}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nature Reserves In Jordan}} [[Category:Geography of Jordan]] [[Category:Nature reserves in Jordan| ]]

revision.text:
<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{double image|right|Flag of Albania.svg|185|Albania state emblem.svg|87|The [[Flag of Albania]]|The [[Coat of arms of Albania]]}} [[File:LocationAlbania.svg|thumb|The location of [[Albania]]]] [[File:Un-albania.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Republic of Albania]]]] {{See also|Index of Albania-related articles}}
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Albania:
'''[[Republic of Albania]]''' – [[List of sovereign states|sovereign country]] located on the [[Balkan Peninsula]] in [[Southern Europe]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 2, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/al.html|title=Albania|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> It has a coast on the [[Adriatic Sea]] to the west, and on the [[Ionian Sea]] to the southwest. It is less than {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} from [[Italy]], across the [[Strait of Otranto]]. Albania is a [[parliamentary democracy]] that is transforming its economy into a market-oriented system. The Albanian capital, [[Tirana]], is home to 350,000 of the country's 3.6 million population. As a result of the opening of the country in the post-communist era, Albania is now undergoing a development boom as its telecommunications, transport and utilities infrastructure is being revamped.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == [[File:Albania-map-en.svg|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Albania]]]] * Pronunciation: {{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-Albania.ogg|æ|l|ˈ|b|eɪ|n|i|ə}} {{respell|al|BAY|nee-ə}} * Common English country name: [[Albania]] * Official English country name: The [[Republic of Albania]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages]] Shqipëria/Shqipëri, Shqipnia/Shqipni * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states]] Republika e Shqipërisë * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Albanian (disambiguation)|Albanian]] <!-- This disambiguation page is the only page on Wikipedia that specifically explains this term and its country adjectival contexts, and it does so excellently. Please leave this link in place. --> * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): Albanian ({{lang-sq|Shqiptar}}) * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Albania]] * [[International rankings of Albania]] * [[ISO country codes]]: AL, ALB, 008 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:AL]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.al]]
== Geography of Albania == [[File:Albania map-en.svg|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Albania]]]]
[[Geography of Albania]] * Albania is: a [[country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]] ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] *** [[Eurasia]] **** [[Europe]] ***** [[Southern Europe]] ****** [[Balkans]] (also known as "Southeastern Europe") ** [[Time zone]]: [[Central European Time]] ([[UTC+01]]), [[Central European Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) ** [[Extreme points of Albania]] *** High: [[Golem Korab|Maja e Korabit]] {{convert|2764|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Adriatic Sea]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: 717 km ::{{Flag|Greece}} 282 km ::{{Flag|Montenegro}} 172 km ::{{Flag|Macedonia}} 151 km ::{{Flag|Kosovo}} 112 km :*Coastline: 362 km * [[Population of Albania]]: 3,600,523 people (2007 [[Approximation|estimate]]) - [[List of countries by population|130th most populous country]] * [[Area of Albania]]: {{convert|28748|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} - [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|139th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Albania|Atlas of Albania]]
=== Environment of Albania === [[File:Albania space.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Albania]]]]
[[Environment of Albania]] * [[Climate of Albania]] * [[Protected areas of Albania]] ** [[List of national parks of Albania|National parks of Albania]] * [[Wildlife of Albania]] ** [[Fauna of Albania]] *** [[List of birds of Albania|Birds of Albania]] *** [[List of mammals of Albania|Mammals of Albania]]
==== Natural geographic features of Albania ==== * [[Glaciers of Albania]] * [[List of islands of Albania|Islands of Albania]] * [[List of lakes in Albania|Lakes of Albania]] * [[List of mountains in Albania|Mountains of Albania]] * [[List of rivers of Albania|Rivers of Albania]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in Europe#Albania|World Heritage Sites in Albania]]
=== Regions of Albania ===
[[Regions of Albania]] ==== Ecoregions of Albania ====
[[List of ecoregions in Albania]] * [[Ecoregions in Albania]]
==== Administrative divisions of Albania ====
[[Administrative divisions of Albania]] * [[Counties of Albania]] ** [[Municipalities of Albania]]
===== Counties of Albania ===== [[File:AlbaniaNumberedPrefectures.svg|thumb|Counties of Albania]]
[[Albania]] is divided into twelve counties ({{lang-sq|qarku}}, [[Grammatical number|sing.]] ''qark'' (official term); but often ''prefektura'', sing. ''prefekturë'', sometimes translated as [[prefecture]]). Each contains several [[Municipalities of Albania|municipalities]]:<ref>[http://www.reformaterritoriale.al/images/presentations/Ligji%20ndarja%20territoriale_Fletore_zyrtare.pdf Law nr. 115/2014] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924085559/http://www.reformaterritoriale.al/images/presentations/Ligji%20ndarja%20territoriale_Fletore_zyrtare.pdf |date=2015-09-24 }}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Picture the Homeless''' (PTH) is an American [[homelessness|homeless]] person–led rights organization founded in 1999<ref name=NYT>Stewart, Nikita, "Born of Homelessness, a Group Takes Stock of Its Policy Victories," The New York Times, 23 December 2017, p. A20.</ref> based in the [[New York, New York]]. It focuses on [[human rights]], [[Housing|housing]], [[police violence]] and other [[social justice]] issues. It was housed originally in [[Judson Memorial Church]], which still hosts its Longest Night of the Year [[memorial]] event, and was located for a time in [[Spanish Harlem|El Barrio]] and 2427 Morris Avenue in the [[Bronx]]. It is currently based on 126th Street in [[Manhattan]].
==Profile==
The group is a [[nonprofit]] organization whose goal is to end homelessness. It believes that people who are homeless must become an organized, effective voice for systemic change. PTH attempts to develop [[leadership]] among homeless people to impact policies and systems that affect their lives. They also endeavor to create space for them, and their agenda, within the broader social justice movement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.picturethehomeless.org/home/about/ |title=Picture the Homeless: About Us}}</ref> They are strong proponents of diverting funds from the [[New York City Department of Homeless Services]] out of the shelter system and into [[community land trust]]s.<ref>Scott Andrew Hutchins representing Picture the Homeless at Studio X, October 29, 2013. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m9TgUSxdGTU</ref><ref>Ryan Gibbs representing Picture the Homeless at [[Monroe College]], October 12, 2013. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zzzlQJ-Lx5Q</ref> To this end, the organization founded a [[coalition]] called [[The New York City Community Land Initiative]] with [[The New Economy Project]] and other groups.<ref>Brendan O'Oonnor. "The Ungentrifiers: Hiding affordable apartments from a ravenous market." ''The Awl''. July 30th, 2015 http://nyf.org/newsmakers/picture-the-homeless-and-new-economy-project-quoted-in-report-on-community-land-trusts-in-feature-on-the-awl/</ref>
''New York Times'' writer Nikita Stewart in December 2017 described it as "one of the nation's few advocacy organizations founded by homeless people and led by people who are experiencing or have experienced homelessness" and that "the group has made itself a formidable influence on city policy."<ref name=NYT/>
==Campaigns==
*[[Civil Rights]] - Picture the Homeless is involved in a number of civil rights campaigns with a large focus on anti-police brutality [[protest]]s and [[court case]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nyclu.org/en/cases/picture-homeless-v-city-new-york-challenging-nypds-singling-out-homeless|title=Picture the Homeless v. City of New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indypressny.org/nycma/voices/434/briefs/briefs_5/|title=Protest against NYPD arrests of the homeless}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.picturethehomeless.org/blog/policingeditiorial|title=a PTH member's editorial on police harassment|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803143843/http://www.picturethehomeless.org/blog/policingeditiorial|archivedate=2010-08-03|df=}}</ref> *Housing - The organization believes that [[right to housing|housing is a human right]] and that access to housing is in crisis in New York City. Their campaigns have included fighting for [[affordable housing]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.picturethehomeless.org/blog/hnwapril|title=Housing Not Warehousing Campaign|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803143747/http://www.picturethehomeless.org/blog/hnwapril|archivedate=2010-08-03|df=}}</ref> Their actions have included occupying buildings and vacant lots.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indypendent.org/2009/03/19/east-harlem-residents-and-housing-advocates-rally/|title=East Harlem Residents, Housing Advocates Rally Outside Vacant Building}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/activists-for-homeless-occupy-east-harlem-lot/|title=Activists Arrested After Occupying East Harlem Lot|publisher=New York Times | first=Colin | last=Moynihan | date=2009-07-23}}</ref>
==International connections==
In 2009 four members of Picture the Homeless traveled to [[Budapest, Hungary]] to meet homeless and other activists, present their work in New York and to mutually exchange experiences. In Budapest, the group was instrumental in founding Hungary’s first homeless-led advocacy group called A Város Mindenkié ([[The City is For All]]).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indypendent.org/2009/09/09/homeless-in-hungary/ |title=Homeless in Hungary|publisher=The Indypendent}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Homelessness organizations]] [[Category:Urban planning organizations]] [[Category:Affordable housing advocacy organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Organizations based in the Bronx]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1999]]

revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} [[File:Antarctica Station Map.png|thumb|300px|Map shows the location of permanent Antarctic research stations]] [[Image:Antarctican bases.png|thumb|300px|Countries that have one or more stations in Antarctica]] A number of governments have set up permanent research stations in Antarctica and these bases are widely distributed. Unlike the [[drifting ice station]]s set up in the [[Arctic]], the [[research station]]s of the [[Antarctic]] are constructed either on rock or on ice that is (for practical purposes) fixed in place. Many of the stations are [[Demographics of Antarctica|staffed]] around the year. A total of 40 countries (as of October 2006), all signatories to the [[Antarctic Treaty System|Antarctic Treaty]], operate seasonal (summer) and year-round research stations on the continent. The population of people performing and supporting scientific research on the continent and nearby islands varies from approximately 4,000 during the summer season to 1,000 during winter (June).{{cite journal|author1=Silja Vöneky|author2=Sange Addison-Agyei|authorlink1=Silja Vöneky|title=Oxford Public International Law|journal=Max Planck Encyclopedia of Public International Law|date=May 2011}} In addition to these permanent stations, approximately [[Antarctic field camps|30 field camps]] are established each summer to support specific projects.[https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/1997/antpanel/4past.htm 4.0 Antarctica - Past and Present]{{Dubious|date=August 2011}} ==History== ===First bases=== [[File:Omond House - Laurie Island.jpg|thumb|300px|"Omond House", the first permanent base, built in 1903 by the [[Scottish National Antarctic Expedition]]]] During the [[Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration]] in the late 19th century, the first bases on the continent were established. In 1898, [[Carsten Borchgrevink]], a Norwegian/British explorer, led the British Antarctic Expedition to [[Cape Adare]], where he established the first Antarctic base on Ridley Beach. The expedition is often referred to now as the [[Southern Cross Expedition|'Southern Cross' Expedition]], after their ship's name. Most of the staff were Norwegian, but the funds for the expedition were British, provided by Sir [[George Newnes]]. The 10 members of the expedition explored Robinson Bay to the west of Cape Adare by dog teams, and later, after being picked up by the ship at the base, went ashore on the Ross Ice Shelf for brief journeys. The expedition hut is still in good condition and visited frequently by tourists. The hut was later occupied by Scott's Northern Party under the command of [[Victor Campbell (Royal Navy officer)|Victor Campbell]] for a year in 1911, after its attempt to explore the eastern end of the ice shelf discovered [[Roald Amundsen]] already ashore preparing for his assault on the South Pole. In 1903, Dr [[William Speirs Bruce|William S. Bruce]]'s [[Scottish National Antarctic Expedition]] set off to Antarctica, with one of its aims to establish a meteorological station in the area. After the expedition failed to find land, Bruce decided to head back to the Laurie Island in the [[South Orkneys]] and find an anchorage there.{{cite book|last1=Rudmose Brown|first1=R. N.|last2=Pirie|first2=J. H.|last3=Mossman|first3=R. C.|title=The Voyage of the Scotia|publisher=Mercat Press|location= Edinburgh|year=2002|isbn=1-84183-044-5|pages=34–57}} The islands were well-situated as a site for a meteorological station, and their relative proximity to the [[South American]] mainland allowed a permanent station to be established.{{sfn|Rudmose Brown|p=57}} Bruce instituted a comprehensive programme of work, involving meteorological readings, trawling for marine samples, botanical excursions, and the collection of biological and geological specimens. The major task completed during this time was the construction of a stone building, christened "Omond House".{{cite web|title=Voyage of the ''Scotia'' 1902–04: The Antarctic|url=http://gdl.cdlr.strath.ac.uk/scotia/vsindexantarctic.html|publisher=Glasgow Digital Library|accessdate=2008-06-30}} This was to act as living accommodation for the parties that would remain on Laurie Island to operate the proposed meteorological laboratory. The building was constructed from local materials using the [[dry stone]] method, with a roof improvised from wood and canvas sheeting. The completed house was 20 feet by 20 feet square (6m × 6m), with two windows, fitted as quarters for six people. Rudmose Brown wrote: "Considering that we had no [[mortar (masonry)|mortar]] and no [[stonemasonry#Tools|masons' tools]] it is a wonderfully fine house and very lasting. I should think it will be standing a century hence ..."{{cite book | last = Speak | first = Peter | year = 2003 | title = William Speirs Bruce: Polar Explorer and Scottish Nationalist | publisher = NMS Publishing | location = Edinburgh | isbn = 1-901663-71-X |page=85}} Bruce later offered to [[Argentina]] the transfer of the station and instruments on the condition that the government committed itself to the continuation of the scientific mission.{{cite web | url=http://www.ucema.edu.ar/ceieg/arg-rree/7/7-107.htm | title=Historia General de las Relaciones Exteriores de la Republica Argentina | accessdate=July 6, 2012 | author1=Escude, Carlos |author2=Cisneros, Andres |language=Spanish}} Bruce informed the British officer William Haggard of his intentions in December 1903, and Haggard ratified the terms of Bruce proposition.{{cite book | title=Cuatro Años en las Orcadas del Sur | publisher=Ediciones Peuser | author=Moneta, Jose Manuel | edition=9th | year=1954}} The ''Scotia'' sailed back for Laurie Island on 14 January 1904 carrying on board Argentinean officials from the Ministry of Agriculture, National Meteorological Office, Ministry of Livestock and National Postal and Telegraphs Office. In 1906, Argentina communicated to the international community the establishment of a permanent base on South Orkney Islands. ===WWII and postwar expansion=== Little happened for the following forty years until the [[Second World War]], when the British launched [[Operation Tabarin]] in 1943, to establish a presence on the continent. The chief reason was to establish solid British claims to various uninhabited islands and parts of Antarctica, reinforced by Argentine sympathies toward Germany. [[File:Base Arturo Prat .JPG|thumb|left|View of Chile's [[Captain Arturo Prat Base]], established in 1947]] Prior to the start of the war, German aircraft had dropped markers with swastikas across [[Queen Maud Land]] in an attempt to create a territorial claim, see [[New Swabia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spri.cam.ac.uk/library/pictures/catalogue/hmscc1943/|title=HMS Carnarvon Castle 1943|publisher=}} Led by Lieutenant [[James William Slessor Marr|James Marr]], the 14-strong team left the [[Falkland Islands]] in two ships, [[RRS William Scoresby|HMS ''William Scoresby'']] (a minesweeping trawler) and ''Fitzroy'', on Saturday January 29, 1944. Marr had accompanied the British explorer Sir [[Ernest Shackleton]] on his final Antarctic expedition in 1921 - 1922. Bases were established during February near the abandoned [[Norway|Norwegian]] whaling station on [[Deception Island]], where the [[Union Flag]] was hoisted in place of Argentine flags, and at [[Port Lockroy]] (on February 11) on the coast of [[Graham Land]]. A further base was founded at [[Hope Bay]] on February 13, 1945, after a failed attempt to unload stores on February 7, 1944. These bases were the first ever to be constructed on the mainland Antarctica.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/antarctica/robert-falcon-scott/9706157/Spirit-of-Scott-2012-Britains-polar-interests-lie-under-a-cloud.html|title=Spirit of Scott 2012: Britain’s polar interests lie under a cloud|publisher=The Daily Telegraph}} The Operation provoked a massive expansion in international activity after the war. Chile organized its [[First Chilean Antarctic Expedition]] in 1947–48. Among other accomplishments, it brought the Chilean president [[Gabriel González Videla]] to personally inaugurate one of its bases, thereby becoming the first head of state to set foot on the continent.Antarctica and the Arctic: the complete encyclopedia, Volume 1, by David McGonigal, Lynn Woodworth, page 98 [[Signy Research Station]] (UK) was established in 1947, Australia's [[Mawson Station]] in 1954, [[Dumont d'Urville Station]] was the first French station in 1956. In that same year, the United States built [[McMurdo Station]] and [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]], and the Soviet Union built [[Mirny Station]]. ==List of research stations== The United States maintains the southernmost Base and the largest base and research station in Antarctica, [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]]. The second-southernmost base is the Chinese [[Kunlun Station]] at 80°25′02″S during the summer season, and the Russian [[Vostok Station]] at 78°27′50″S during the winter season. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:99%" |- align="center" bgcolor="#cccccc" ! Station
